header_summary:
Josh Doman emphasized the potential benefits of integrating secp256r1 (P256) support into Bitcoin, highlighting its widespread adoption in devices and the opportunity to enhance user experience and security through self-custody. He argued that despite historical concerns over NIST's potential backdoor in P256 and its slower validation compared to secp256k1, the advantages, including improved onboarding and hot wallet security, outweigh these issues. Tapscript's introduction further simplifies incorporating P256 by supporting new public key types, suggesting a reevaluation of P256's role in Bitcoin's ecosystem is timely ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/8fbe1fe3-425d-4056-8387-993f6ecc1been@googlegroups.com/T/#u#mca69ad88296255cb304bb3f4c79e85cde6424d81)).

Tim Ruffing announced the release of version 0.7.0 of libsecp256k1, marking significant maintenance improvements and API, ABI compatibility enhancements. This update, which includes support for CMake and deprecates old function aliases for private key operations, aims to improve the library's stability and efficiency for developers within the Bitcoin ecosystem, reflecting the maintainers' commitment to a robust cryptographic library ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/659ec12e5b034d5c20ef15d88325e740a29c8182.camel@real-or-random.org/T/#u#m6b98ac4d6705500614b97ab9f4dc07b86ceaba34)).

Jon Atack expressed satisfaction with the current collaborative dynamics within the Bitcoin development group, attributing the smooth coordination and effective management of the repository to the active day-to-day involvement of himself and Murch, along with the support of other editors. This structure has facilitated an efficient and enjoyable collaboration experience, particularly in handling Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs) issues ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/8285fb0c-119b-42b8-a530-194650b87ebe@achow101.com/T/#mee9e8028310ff77b76459611a8e1d91a09b3ee20)).

A new dataset and benchmarking tool released by zpv provides valuable data for Bitcoin block fee spans and fee estimations from January to June 2025. This initiative aims to enhance transparency and collaborative improvement in cryptocurrency research by enabling users to reproduce results and contribute feedback, underscoring a commitment to advancing the field ([source](https://github.com/block/bitcoin-augur-benchmarking)).

recent_posts.title: Revisiting secp256r1 signatures (i.e. P256, mobile HSM support)
recent_posts.summary:
- Discussions on adding P256 to Bitcoin have been sparse since 2011 and 2013.
- P256 adoption could improve user onboarding, security, and reduce multi-signature costs.
- Technical updates and hardware adoption suggest revisiting P256 support in Bitcoin.

recent_posts.title: libsecp256k1 v0.7.0 released
recent_posts.summary:
- Version 0.7.0 of libsecp256k1 focuses on maintenance and API/ABI compatibility improvements.
- It introduces constant pointers for type safety and deprecates old private key function aliases.
- The update supports CMake, facilitating easier developer integration, alongside continued GNU Autotools support.

recent_posts.title: New BIP Editors: 1 Year Later
recent_posts.summary:
- Jon appreciates the group's dynamics, highlighting active engagement in managing the repository.
- Coordination is eased by having a limited number directly involved, preventing complications.
- Contributions from less visible editors are significant, especially in BIPs discussions.

recent_posts.title: Augur: Block’s Open Source Bitcoin Fee Estimation Library
recent_posts.summary:
- A new dataset and benchmarking tool for Bitcoin fee analysis has been released.
- It includes data ranging from January 2025 to June 2025, supporting various cryptocurrency stakeholders.
- The project promotes community feedback and collaborative improvement, with resources available on GitHub.

recent_posts.title: Disclosure: LND gossip_timestamp_filter DoS
recent_posts.summary:
- A recent network security incident involved an ineffective stealth attack mitigation on the Lightning Network.
- The mitigation strategy's flaw, admitting personal responsibility, was publicly documented on GitHub.
- This transparency illustrates the open-source community's collaborative effort to address and learn from security challenges.

recent_posts.title: Post-Quantum HD-Wallets, Silent Payments, Key Aggregation, and Threshold Signatures
recent_posts.summary:
- Evaluating post-quantum cryptography is vital to surpass current standards like ECDSA.
- Significant efficiency gains in Musig/Frost schemes show potential for better cryptographic protocols.
- The goal is to find practical, quantum-resistant solutions for future cybersecurity enhancements.

active_posts.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
active_posts.summary:
- Jameson Lopp's blog post proposes enhancing Bitcoin's resilience to quantum threats.
- It suggests a phased adoption of post-quantum cryptographic standards and a new P2QRH output type.
- The proposal emphasizes a collective move to quantum-resistant cryptography to protect Bitcoin's network integrity.

active_posts.title: A Taproot-native (re-)bindable transaction bundle proposal
active_posts.summary:
- Antoine Poinsot, Steven Roose, and Greg Sanders developed a Bitcoin improvement proposal.
- Their proposal introduces `OP_TEMPLATEHASH`, enhancing Bitcoin by simplifying operations.
- It is designed to be Taproot native, improving efficiency and avoiding legacy issues.

active_posts.title: DahLIAS: Discrete Logarithm-Based Interactive Aggregate Signatures
active_posts.summary:
- DahLIAS introduces a first-of-its-kind interactive aggregate signature compatible with secp256k1.
- It offers significant reductions in transaction sizes and verification costs for Bitcoin transactions.
- Despite past challenges, DahLIAS ensures security without key tweaking and enhances operational efficiency.

active_posts.title: Stats on compact block reconstructions
active_posts.summary:
- Exploration of Bitcoin block reconstructions demonstrates variations based on node configurations and mempool activity.
- Adjustments like `mempoolfullrbf=1` significantly improve compact block reconstruction efficiency.
- Analysis suggests potential network-wide benefits from policy adjustments and further research into reconstruction optimization.

active_posts.title: Changes to BIP-360 - Pay to Quantum Resistant Hash (P2QRH)
active_posts.summary:
- BIP-360 updates enhance Bitcoin's defense against quantum computing by altering P2QRH to P2TR.
- The proposal simplifies protection methods and provides time for adaptation against quantum threats.
- It outlines a plan for Post-Quantum signatures, ensuring flexibility and future-proofing Bitcoin.

active_posts.title: Exploring Extended Relative Timelocks
active_posts.summary:
- Users of Liana explore extending Bitcoin timelocks to ~10 years due to demand.
- A proposed method suggests using bit 21 in `nSequence` for longer timelocks, multiplying duration by 8.
- The initiative includes tools for testing, while addressing potential risks and seeking community feedback.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP 118 and SIGHASH_ANYPREVOUT
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- ZmnSCPxj discussed a Taproot version of eltoo for Lightning Dev, using a shared taproot pubkey.
- Update transactions use `SIGHASH_ANYPREVOUTANYSCRIPT`, state transactions require specific script commitment.
- Richard queried the efficiency of key-path versus script-path spending and signature round trips.

today_in_history_posts.title: Dynamic Commitments: Upgrading Channels Without On-Chain Transactions
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rusty discusses implementing double-opt-in via `commit_switch` messages, maintaining an "initiator" system.
- He suggests a linear improvement in channel types and utilizing existing feature bits for upgrades.
- Rusty outlines upgrading to anchor_outputs in steps and emphasizes the need for a feature bit for upgrades.

today_in_history_posts.title: Bolt 12 Trusted Contacts
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bolt 12 enhances lightning wallets by integrating offers with metadata for easier payments.
- It proposes selective identity revelation to balance transaction simplicity with privacy.
- Feedback is sought to refine selective identity standards without compromising security.
